message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Caspase-3 is a common component of all three mechanisms of initiating programmed cellular death. Bax and Bcl-2 are involved in the first mechanism, while CD-95 protein is involved in the second mechanism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Caspase-3 plays a central role in all three aforementioned mechanisms of programmed cellular death. Bax and Bcl-2 are members of a protein family that regulate apoptosis, but they are not involved in all three mechanisms. CD-95 protein is involved in transmembrane receptor-mediated interaction, but not the other two.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Caspase-3 is involved in all three biochemical mechanisms of initiating programmed cellular death. Caspase-3 is a protease that cleaves specific cellular targets in the process of apoptosis, which is programmed cell death.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The question is asking for a common biochemical component involved in all three pathways of programmed cell death. Caspase-3 is a cysteine protease that plays a central role in the execution phase of cell apoptosis in all three pathways. Bax and Bcl-2 are proteins involved in the mitochondrial-initiated events, and CD-95 protein is involved in transmembrane receptor-mediated interaction.

We refer to scientific articles on cell biology and apoptosis for help. Caspase-3, also known as CPP32, is a protease enzyme that plays a central role in both intrinsic and extrinsic pathways of apoptosis. It is involved in the activation of other caspases, cleavage of cellular proteins, and ultimately, execution of programmed cell death. Bax and Bcl-2 are proteins that regulate the permeability of the mitochondrial membrane, while CD-95 protein (also known as Fas) is an integral membrane protein that functions in the extrinsic pathway of apoptosis. Only Caspase-3 is involved in all three of the biochemical mechanisms listed. Therefore, it plays a common role in programmed cellular death.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The question asks for a common biochemical component involved in all three mechanisms of initiating programmed cellular death. Caspase-3 is a common downstream effector of all three mechanisms, making it the correct answer. Bax and Bcl-2 are involved in only one of the mechanisms, while CD-95 protein is not involved in any of the mechanisms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Caspase-3 is a key mediator in all 3 known mechanisms of programmed cell death, making it the common biochemical component in all of them. Bax and Bcl-2 are associated with mitochondrial-initiated events, while CD-95 protein is associated with transmembrane receptor-mediated interaction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, Caspase-3 is the only enzyme that plays a key role in all three mechanisms of programmed cellular death. Caspase-3 is activated by both extrinsic (transmembrane receptor-mediated interaction and release of cytoplasmic granules) and intrinsic (stimuli producing intracellular signals leading to mitochondrial-initiated events) pathways.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the 3 mechanisms listed, all of them involve activation of caspases, a family of cysteine proteases that play essential roles in apoptosis. Therefore, the correct answer is (A) Caspase-3. Bax and Bcl-2 are proteins involved in regulating apoptosis, but they do not play a role in all 3 mechanisms listed. CD-95 protein is only involved in transmembrane receptor-mediated interaction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Caspase-3 plays a common role in all 3 types of programmed cellular death. It is a protease involved in the downstream signaling of all apoptosis pathways. Bax and Bcl-2 are involved in the mitochondrial pathway, while CD-95 protein is involved in the receptor pathway.
